head.title: Ever More People, Ever Fewer Fish

hedline.hl1: Ever More People, Ever Fewer Fish

abstract.p: Robert F LaPorta letter on Sept 13 editorial blames overpopulation for depletion of fish stocks; drawing (M)

block.p: As you say in a Sept. 13 editorial, many of the world's fish stocks are at risk of being depleted. The cause of this depletion is easy to understand, since it is the same reason there is continued loss of the rain forest and an increase in the greenhouse effect: overpopulation.

As you say in a Sept. 13 editorial, many of the world's fish stocks are at risk of being depleted. The cause of this depletion is easy to understand, since it is the same reason there is continued loss of the rain forest and an increase in the greenhouse effect: overpopulation.

Recent estimates that the world population will level off to 9 billion to 10 billion people in 50 years are cause for serious concern. The planet appears unable to support the number of human beings now on earth; a larger population will only worsen problems for both humanity and the environment.
ROBERT F. LA PORTA Dix Hills, N.Y., Sept. 14, 1998
